courseDescription: This course offers a non-technical introduction to the emerging and interdisciplinary area of data science. Students will be introduced to the development, fundamental tools, and the impact of data science in a wide range of disciplines such as business, the sciences and engineering. Fundamental data visualization techniques and basic concepts of machine learning will be applied through real-life data science projects. Moreover, students will explore the general framework for ethical thinking and practicing data science, the current challenges, the benefits, the potential harms and risks posed by developing data science models and technology.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating on real-life data science projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying potential harms and risks in data science models
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding the general framework for ethical data science

courseDescription: An introductory course on programming languages and tools which are relevant to data analytics. Each language or tool is introduced as a separate module and incorporates applications in mathematics and statistics. Examples of included programming languages and tools are MATLAB, Python, R and SAS. Additional languages and tools may be covered based on current trends in data analytics. Students will complete hands-on programming assignments throughout the course.

An introductory course on machine learning. Machine Learning is the science of discovering pattern and structure and making predictions in data sets. It lies at the interface of mathematics, statistics and computer science. The course gives an elementary summary of modern machine learning tools. Topics include regression, classification, regularization, resampling methods, and unsupervised learning. Students enrolled are expected to have some ability to write computer programs, some knowledge of probability, statistics and linear algebra.
Technical and Digital Skills: Mathematical understanding of regression and classification algorithms
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining complex ML concepts to non-technical stakeholders
Collaborating with team members on ML projects
Presenting findings from ML models to diverse audiences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Selecting appropriate ML algorithms for specific tasks
Optimizing model performance through iterative experimentation
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing ML project timelines and resources
Coordinating team efforts in developing ML solutions
Setting priorities in ML project tasks

courseTitle: Modern Statistical Methods for Big Data Analytics
courseDescription: The statistical perspective of data mining is emphasized for majority of the course. Both applied aspects (programming, problem solving, and data analysis) and theoretical concepts (learning, understanding, and evaluating methodologies) of data mining will be covered. Topics include Regularization and Kernel Smoothing Methods, Tree-based Methods, Neural Networks and optional topics such as deep learning.

courseTitle: Introduction to Optimization in Data Science
courseDescription: Topics considered include the solution of non-smooth optimization problems arising in data science, including unconstrained and constrained optimization problems, Lagrange multiplier methods, inequality constraints, Kuhn-Tucker conditions, and applications. Also considered are linear and nonlinear inverse problems, regularization of ill-posed problem including singular value decomposition, and Tikhonov regularization methods and sparse regularization methods,  inverse eigenvalue problems and applications such as compressed sensing, image reconstruction and machine learning.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of optimization techniques to real-world problems

courseTitle: Senior Project in Big Data Analytics I
courseDescription: This course introduces students to practical applications of big data analytics. Lecture topics include an overview of the various topics in business, engineering, and government currently using big data analytics. Students will choose a project involving a real world application to explore techniques learned during other course work. Course involves written and oral presentations for students to improve communication and teamwork skills.
Technical and Digital Skills: Big data analytics tools (e.g., Hadoop, Spark)
Machine learning algorithms for big data analysis
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective written and oral presentation skills for project findings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying patterns and trends in large datasets
Optimizing algorithms for big data processing
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for big data projects
Delegating tasks within a project team

courseTitle: Senior Project in Big Data Analytics II
courseDescription: This course allows the student to pursue an in-depth exploration of a project initiated in BDA 450. The course involves written and oral presentations for students to improve communication and teamwork skills.
Technical and Digital Skills: Big data processing frameworks (e.g., Hadoop, Spark)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective written and oral presentation skills
Providing constructive feedback to team members
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying patterns and trends in large datasets
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management skills for big data projects
Delegating tasks and responsibilities within a team

This course will introduce mathematical foundations of machine learning theory and algorithms. Topics include statistical learning theory, kernel methods and generative models. Some modern machine learning methods such as dictionary learning, deep learning, online learning, and reinforcement learning may also be included, time permitting. Students enrolled are expected to have some knowledge of probability, linear algebra, optimization, and analysis.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of machine learning algorithms
Analyzing and interpreting machine learning results

courseDescription: This course will introduce optimization methods for large-scale problems by exploiting special structures including convexity and sparsity. Topics include introduction to convexity, gradient-related methods, dual methods, sparse optimization methods and nonconvex optimization methods. Students enrolled are expected to have some knowledge of linear algebra, optimization, probability, and analysis.

Under the guidance of a faculty member in the Department of Mathematics and Statistics, the student will undertake a significant computational data analysis problem. A written report and/or public presentation of results will be required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data visualization using tools like Tableau or Matplotlib
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective presentation of data analysis results
Collaborative software development using platforms like Git
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Optimization techniques for model performance improvement
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for data analytics projects

courseDescription: Introductory discussion on central dogma of molecular biology, concepts of transcription, translation, gene regulation, and the need for high throughput methods. Other topics covered are Introduction to R and Bioconductor, Advanced microarray data analysis, NGS data analysis using edgeR in Bioconductor, Network Biology, sequence, pathway informatics, SNPs, GWAS, informatics for genome variants.
Technical and Digital Skills: R programming for genomic data analysis
Bioconductor usage for NGS data analysis

courseDescription: Techniques for obtaining basic tail bounds and concentration inequalities, uniform laws of large numbers, Rademacher complexity of a set, covering and packing in metric spaces, and metric entropy. Also, high dimensional random matrices described in a non-asymptotic framework, with a focus on the estimation of sparse and structured covariance matrix, are studied. The sparse linear regression models and the principal component analysis in the unstructured and sparse setting will be covered.
Technical and Digital Skills: Principal component analysis in unstructured and sparse setting

courseDescription: An introduction to the statistical analysis of sample curves or functions. Topics include smoothing, registration, functional principal component analysis, scalar-on-function regression, and functional response models. All these techniques will be applied using the statistical software R.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Data interpretation for curves or functions
Model selection for functional data analysis

courseDescription: Various transform methods from the data domain to coefficients of the data in certain discrete bases are studied. Transforms studied include FFT, DCT, wavelet transforms and framelet transform. Both theory and applications of these transforms are covered.
